marketNews.title: Wholesales Mobil +2% YoY in Feb-25, First Since Jun-23
marketNews.content: Gaikindo reported that national automobile wholesales in February 2025 reached 72,295 units, a 2.2 percent year‑on‑year increase and a 17 percent month‑on‑month rise, marking the first annual growth since June 2023. The result brings total 2‑month (January‑February) 2025 wholesales to 134,144 units, down 4.5 percent year‑on‑year, representing 15‑18 percent of Gaikindo's 2025 target of 750,000‑900,000 units (compared with 2‑month 2024, which was 16.2 percent of the 2024 realization). Highlights: 1) ASII relative weakness – market share fell. Combined, the two main Astra International brands, Toyota and Daihatsu, recorded a 5.8 percent year‑on‑year decline and a 13 percent month‑on‑month increase in February 2025, performing worse than the industry average of +2.2 percent year‑on‑year and +17 percent month‑on‑month. Their combined market share dropped to 50.3 percent in February 2025 (versus 54.6 percent in February 2024 and 51.8 percent in January 2025). Over the first two months of 2025, Toyota and Daihatsu wholesales totaled 68,421 units, down 7.5 percent year‑on‑year, also weaker than the industry decline of 4.5 percent year‑on‑year, resulting in a combined market share of 51 percent (versus 52.6 percent in 2‑month 2024 and 51.8 percent in January 2025). 2) Main competitors outperformed ASII. Among the top three competitors, Mitsubishi posted the strongest performance with 8,790 units sold in February 2025, up 6.6 percent year‑on‑year and 23 percent month‑on‑month, raising its market share to 12.2 percent (versus 11.6 percent in February 2024 and 11.5 percent in January 2025). Suzuki recorded a decline to 4,750 units, down 4.9 percent year‑on‑year and 4.7 percent month‑on‑month, but its decline was still milder than Toyota and Daihatsu. 3) Chinese brands surged. Wuling and Chery posted sales jumps of +61 percent year‑on‑year and +241 percent year‑on‑year respectively in February 2025. Chery sold 1,468 units, the highest since the brand entered Indonesia, driven by the launch of the Tiggo Cross at the Indonesia International Motor Show (IIMS) 2025. BYD sold 1,399 units, remaining relatively stable compared with the average of the previous two months.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: We assess that the relatively good sales volume – allowing year‑on‑year growth – was driven by solid IIMS 2025 sales and a seasonal demand shift related to Lebaran that moved slightly into February 2025. IIMS 2025 was considered successful, recording a 16 percent year‑on‑year increase in sales to 22,322 units. In our view, the success of IIMS 2025 indicates that consumers responded positively to the new models launched, supporting a recovery of national automobile sales this year.

marketNews.title: Menteri Ketenagakerjaan, Yassierli, orders THR payment before Lebaran
marketNews.content: Labor Minister Yassierli on Tuesday (11 March) ordered private companies and state‑owned enterprises to disburse the Hari Raya (THR) allowance at least seven days (H‑7) before Lebaran 2025. The THR must be paid in full and cannot be paid in installments.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia reports decline in Consumer Confidence Index
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia recorded that the Consumer Confidence Index (IKK) fell to 126.4 in February 2025 (down from 127.2 in January 2025), marking a second consecutive month of decline although it remained at an optimistic level. The drop was driven by a decrease in all sub‑indices of consumer expectations (IEK), which fell to 138.7 (versus 140.8 in January 2025). Meanwhile, the current economic conditions index (IKE) rose to 114.2 (versus 113.5 in January 2025), even as the sub‑index for job availability fell by 1.5 points to 106.2.

marketNews.title: Goldman Sachs downgrades Indonesia rating
marketNews.content: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. lowered its rating on Indonesian assets, citing rising fiscal risk from a series of initiatives by President Prabowo Subianto. Goldman Sachs cut its rating on Indonesian equities from overweight to market weight and downgraded the rating on 10‑20 year sovereign bonds to neutral. The downgrade followed Goldman raising its 2025 fiscal deficit forecast from 2.5 percent of GDP to 2.9 percent of GDP.

marketNews.title: US stock markets tumble amid recession and trade war concerns
marketNews.content: U.S. stock markets fell on Monday (10 March) with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 2.08 percent, the S&P 500 down 2.7 percent, and the Nasdaq down 4 percent, as worries grew about a potential recession due to escalating trade wars and a possible U.S. federal government shutdown. The Nasdaq decline marked its largest single‑day drop since September 2022. The day before, President Donald Trump refused to predict whether the United States could avoid a recession amid market concerns over tariffs on U.S. trading partners.

marketNews.title: Celios estimates economic loss from CPNS and PPPK hiring delay
marketNews.content: Bhima Yudhistira, Executive Director of the Center of Economic and Law Studies (Celios), said that the delay in appointing civil servant candidates (CPNS) and government employees on contract (PPPK) will cause a total economic output loss of 11.9 trillion rupiah, based on Celios' input‑output methodology. Celios also projected that the policy will cause a potential loss for businesses of 3.68 trillion rupiah. Previously, the government and parliament agreed to postpone CPNS appointments from the 2024 selection to 1 October 2025, and PPPK appointments to 1 March 2026. The postponement is later than the original schedule, which had CPNS appointments slated for 22 February‑23 March 2025 and PPPK phases 1 and 2 scheduled for February 2025 and July 2025 respectively.

marketNews.title: VinFast plans 100,000 EV charging stations in Indonesia
marketNews.content: Minister of Investment and Downstream Development Rosan Roeslani claimed on Tuesday (11 March) that Vietnamese electric‑vehicle maker VinFast plans to install 100,000 charging stations across Indonesia. VinFast has not commented on the issue. Rosan also updated that VinFast's factory in Subang, West Java, with an annual production capacity of 50,000 units, will start operations in 2026.

marketNews.title: Freeport‑McMoRan seeks copper mineral status in US
marketNews.content: Kathleen Quirk, CEO of Freeport‑McMoRan (NYSE: FCX), said on Monday (10 March) that the company hopes President Donald Trump will designate copper as a strategic mineral. Such a designation would provide tax relief for Freeport‑McMoRan, needed to boost copper production to offset global competition. Previously, Trump told Congress last week that he would dramatically expand production of strategic minerals, though details were not provided. Copper is widely used in power generation, electronics, and construction.

marketNews.title: Indonesian nickel association urges reduction of China dependence
marketNews.content: Djoko Widayatno, member of the Advisory Council of the Indonesian Nickel Miners Association, said on Monday (10 March) that the association is working to reduce the nickel smelter industry's dependence on China, which currently accounts for about 80‑90 percent of Indonesia's nickel consumption. He stated that Indonesian nickel miners must meet international sustainability standards to diversify buyers to alternative markets such as Europe, the United States, and other Asian countries. Earlier, in July 2024, the government told Reuters that Chinese companies were in talks with potential investors to reduce their ownership in Indonesian nickel smelters, a step aimed at helping the industry meet eligibility for U.S. electric‑vehicle tax incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act.

marketNews.title: Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources announces new oil refineries
marketNews.content: Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Bahlil Lahadalia said on Monday (10 March) that Indonesia will build oil refineries in several locations, including Kalimantan and Sulawesi, with a total capacity of one million barrels per day. This amount is double the previously discussed plan for a single refinery with 500,000 barrels per day. The refinery projects are part of 21 downstream projects worth 40 billion US dollars, to be financed by the Danantara Investment Management Agency. Bahlil noted that Indonesia currently imports about one million barrels of crude oil and fuel per day to meet domestic demand.

marketNews.title: Coal DME project and funding details
marketNews.content: Sudirman Widhy, Chairman of the Indonesian Mining Experts Association, said Indonesia has low‑calorie coal reserves of more than 10 billion tons out of a total of 33 billion tons, which can support coal‑to‑dimethyl ether (DME) projects as a substitute for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). However, the DME technology is not yet fully owned by Indonesia and still relies on foreign investment. Previously, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Bahlil Lahadalia said the DME project does not require foreign investors. In 2023, Air Products and Chemicals Inc. withdrew from the DME project with Bukit Asam (PTBA). The DME project is expected to be funded by the Danantara Investment Management Agency with a cost of 11 billion US dollars, representing about 27.5 percent of the total investment for the 21 downstream projects.

marketNews.title: KPPU investigates alleged LPG monopoly by Pertamina Patra Niaga
marketNews.content: The Business Competition Supervisory Commission (KPPU) has begun investigating alleged monopoly practices by PT Pertamina Patra Niaga in the non‑subsidized liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) mid‑stream market. Pertamina Patra Niaga controls more than 80 percent of domestic and imported LPG supply. KPPU found that in 2024 the company recorded profits up to ten times higher from non‑subsidized LPG sales compared with subsidized LPG sales. The investigation will examine the pricing structure of non‑subsidized LPG from upstream to downstream.

tickerNews.title: RAJA clarifies divestment of 4.66% minority stake in RATU
tickerNews.content: Rukun Raharja (RAJA) stated in a clarification to the IDX that the sale of a 4.66 percent stake in Raharja Energi Cepu (RATU) on 5 March 2025 is part of a planned gradual divestment of 10 percent of RATU shares. The company signed a share purchase agreement with buyers on 10 January 2025 at a price of 1,175 rupiah per share. RAJA did not disclose the identities of the buyers, and the buyers are not required to report their shareholdings under OJK regulations. The transaction price was based on the fair value of RATU at the time of signing. The deal aims to strengthen capital structure and provide financial flexibility for RAJA to expand its business.

tickerNews.title: MDKA shares purchased by Saratoga Investama Sedaya
tickerNews.content: The controlling shareholder of Merdeka Copper Gold, Saratoga Investama Sedaya (SRTG), bought approximately 122 million shares of MDKA at a price of 1,405 rupiah per share on 5 March 2025. The total transaction value was about 171 billion rupiah. After the transaction, SRTG's ownership in MDKA increased from 19.58 percent to 20.08 percent.

tickerNews.title: PT Kreasi Jasa Persada acquires shares in Petrosea
tickerNews.content: Petrindo Jaya Kreasi (CUAN) through its subsidiary PT Kreasi Jasa Persada bought approximately 48.5 million shares of Petrosea (PTRO) at an average price of 3,307 rupiah per share on 7 March 2025. The total transaction value was about 160.5 billion rupiah. After the transaction, PT Kreasi Jasa Persada's ownership in PTRO increased from 41.913 percent to 42.394 percent.

tickerNews.title: HRTA signs term sheet with BRMS for gold refining and trade
tickerNews.content: Hartadinata Abadi (HRTA) through its subsidiary PT Emas Murni Abadi signed a term sheet with Bumi Resources Minerals subsidiary PT Gorontalo Minerals (BRMS) for the refining and trade of 5,711 kilograms of gold. Previously, in mid‑February 2025, HRTA also signed a term sheet for the refining and trade of 3,600 kilograms of gold with another BRMS subsidiary, PT Linge Mineral Resources.

tickerNews.title: PGEO considers share buyback amid price decline
tickerNews.content: Yurizki Rio, Director of Pertamina Geothermal Energy (PGEO), said on Monday (10 March) that the company is evaluating a possible share buyback as its stock price has fallen since the second half of 2024 to 815 rupiah per share on Tuesday (11 March), which is 6.9 percent below the IPO price. Yurizki added that management is also reviewing the allocation of funds for the potential buyback.

tickerNews.title: TEBE shares bought by PT Dua Samudera Perkasa
tickerNews.content: The shareholder of the Dana Brata Luhur fund, PT Dua Samudera Perkasa, purchased approximately 39.9 million shares of TEBE at a price of 500 rupiah per share on 7 March 2025. The total transaction value was about 20 billion rupiah. After the transaction, PT Dua Samudera Perkasa's ownership in TEBE increased from 12.5 percent to 15.61 percent.

tickerNews.title: ALII shares sold by Ancara Logistics Indonesia
tickerNews.content: Ancara Logistics Indonesia shareholder Aninditha Anestya Bakrie sold approximately 16.9 million shares of ALII at an average price of 375 rupiah per share between 3 and 6 March 2025. The total transaction value was about 6.3 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Aninditha Anestya Bakrie's ownership in ALII fell from 2.406 percent to 2.3 percent.

tickerNews.title: MENN announces mandatory tender offer
tickerNews.content: The new controlling shareholders of Menn Teknologi Indonesia (MENN) – consisting of PT Penajam Makmur Jaya and five other entities – plan to conduct a mandatory tender offer for 1.42 billion shares (99.05 percent of MENN) at a price of 44 rupiah per share between 15 March and 15 April 2025. The offer price is 51.7 percent higher than MENN's share price on Tuesday (11 March) at 29 rupiah per share. The tender follows MENN's announcement that six companies had purchased 67 percent of MENN shares, with undisclosed value, from three directors and commissioners on 20 February 2025.
